columns.text: In this problem, we will use the concept of adjusted cash flow from assets to solve for the price per share of the company's stock.

From the problem, we currently have the following as the given:


| EBIT| $1,800,000| 
|--|--| 
|Depreciation |$155,000 | 
| Increase in Net Working Capital| $75,000| 
| Capital Spending|$115,000 | 
| Growth rate| 18\%| 
| Debt|$9,500,000 | 
|Outstanding Shares |750,000 | 
| Year 5 growth on adjusted cash flow| 3\%| 
| WACC|8.5\% | 
|Tax Rate |21\% |

In order to solve this, we must first solve for the missing values needed to solve the problem. It is stated that the depreciation, the increase in net working capital, and the capital spending are expected to increase by $18\%$ per year for $4$ years. This means that we can get the succeeding values for the earnings and the depreciation by multiplying the previous year's values by $1.18$ since the growth rate of the values are $18\%$.

For Year 1, the earnings, depreciation, increase in net working capital, and capital spending are already given as $\$1,800,000$ and $\$155,000$, $\$75,000$, $\$115,000$, respectively. Therefore, the earnings, depreciation, change in net working capital, and capital spending for Year 2 are given as:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings for Year 2}&=\$1,800,000 \times 1.18\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,124,000\\[15 pt]
\text{Depreciation for Year 2}&=\$155,000 \times 1.18\\[15 pt]
&=\$182,900\\[15 pt]
\text{Increase in net working capital}&=\$75,000 \times 1.18\\[15 pt]
&=\$88,500\\[15 pt]
\text{Capital spending}&=\$115,000 \times 1.18\\[15 pt]
&=\$135,700
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings, depreciation, increase in net working capital, and capital spending for Year 2 are $\$2,124,000$ and $\$182,900$, $\$88,500$, and $\$135,700$, respectively.

For Year 3:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings for Year 3}&=\$2,124,000 \times 1.18\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,506,320\\[15 pt]
\text{Depreciation for Year 3}&=\$182,900 \times 1.18\\[15 pt]
&=\$215,822\\[15 pt]
\text{Increase in net working capital}&=\$88,500 \times 1.18\\[15 pt]
&=\$104,430\\[15 pt]
\text{Capital spending}&=\$135,700 \times 1.18\\[15 pt]
&=\$160,126
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings, depreciation, increase in net working capital, and capital spending for Year 3 are $\$2,506,320$, $\$215,822$, $\$104,430$, and $\$160,126$, respectively.

For Year 4:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings for Year 4}&=\$2,506,320 \times 1.18\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,957,457.60\\[15 pt]
\text{Depreciation for Year 4}&=\$215,822 \times 1.18\\[15 pt]
&=\$254,669.96\\[15 pt]
\text{Increase in net working capital}&=\$104,430 \times 1.18\\[15 pt]
&=\$123,227.40\\[15 pt]
\text{Capital spending}&=\$160,126 \times 1.18\\[15 pt]
&=\$188,948.68
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings, depreciation, increase in net working capital, and capital spending for Year 4 are $\$2,957,457.60$, $\$254,669.96$, $\$123,227.40$, and $\$188,948.68$, respectively.

Now that we have these values, we can then solve for the taxes for Years 1 to 4. This can easily be solved by multiplying the earnings by the tax rate of $0.21$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Tax for Year 1}&=\$1,800,000 \times 0.21 \\[15 pt]
&=\$378,000\\[15 pt]
\text{Tax for Year 2}&=\$2,124,000 \times 0.21 \\[15 pt]
&=\$446,040\\[15 pt]
\text{Tax for Year 3}&=\$2,506,320 \times 0.21 \\[15 pt]
&=\$526,327.20\\[15 pt]
\text{Tax for Year 4}&=\$2,957,457.60 \times 0.21 \\[15 pt]
&=\$621,066.10
\end{aligned}$$

Now, in order to get the adjusted cash flow from the assets, we will simply use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{CFA*}&=\text{Earnings}+\text{Depreciation}\\
&-(\text{Tax}+\text{Change in net working capital}+\text{Capital spending})
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values for Year 1:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{CFA*}&=\$1,800,000+\$155,000\\
&-(\$378,000+\$75,000+\$115,000)\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,387,000
\end{aligned}$$

The adjusted cash flow for Year 1 is $\$1,387,000$

Substituting the values for Year 2:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{CFA*}&=\$2,124,000+\$182,900\\
&-(\$446,040+\$88,500+\$135,700)\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,636,660
\end{aligned}$$

The adjusted cash flow for Year 2 is $\$1,636,660$

Substituting the values for Year 3:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{CFA*}&=\$2,506,320+\$215,822\\
&-(\$526,327.20+\$104,430+\$160,126)\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,931,258.80
\end{aligned}$$

The adjusted cash flow for Year 3 is $\$1,931,258.80$

Substituting the values for Year 4:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{CFA*}&=\$2,957,457.60+\$254,669.96\\
&-(\$621,066.10+\$123,227.40+\$188,948.68)\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,278,885.38
\end{aligned}$$

The adjusted cash flow for Year 4 is $\$2,278,885.38$

This means that the CFA for Year 4 is the adjusted cash flow plus the Terminal CFA.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash flow for Year 4}&=\$2,278,885.38+\$42,667,308.03\\[15 pt]
&=\$44,946,193.41
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=\dfrac{\$1,387,000}{1.085^1}+\dfrac{\$1,636,660}{1.085^2}\\
&+\dfrac{\$1,931,258.80}{1.085^3}+\dfrac{\$44,946,193.41}{1.085^4}\\[15 pt]
&=\$36,612,626
\end{aligned}$$


The value of the firm is $\$36,612,626$

To get the equity value, we will subtract the value of the debt from the value of the firm:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Equity value}&=\$36,612,626-\$9,500,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$27,112,626
\end{aligned}$$

The equity value of the company is $\$27,112,626$

Now that we have the equity value, we can divide it by the number of outstanding shares to get the price per share of the company's stock.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price per share}&=\dfrac{\$27,112,626}{750,000}\\[15pt]
&=\$36.15
\end{aligned}$$

The price per share of the company's stock is $\$36.15$
